items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Partitioned Popins
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/arichiv/partitioned-popins/
  • Explainer URL: https://github.com/arichiv/partitioned-popins/blob/main/README.md
  • Spec URL: TBD
  • Proposal authors: @arichiv @johannhof @krgovind
  • Bug Tracker URL: https://issues.chromium.org/issues/340606651
  • Chrome Feature URL: TBD
  • Mozillians who can provide input: @bvandersloot-mozilla
  • WebKit standards-position: WebKit/standards-positions#349
  • Tag Review: w3ctag/design-reviews#956

Other information

A new web primitive is needed to cover short-lived popup use cases which require access to storage partitioned by the popup opener. This primitive should be private and secure by default, while providing a consistent UI experience across user agents. To solve this need, we propose the ‚ÄúPartitioned Popin‚Äù, a type of pop-up for loading web content with two unique new features: a modal-like UI relative to its opener tab and cookies/storage being partitioned to its opener context.
items.title: Partitioned Popins

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Reconsidering the SerialPort API position
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/SerialPort
  • Explainer URL (if available): interacting with the plethora of IoT and educational devices out there https://pyscript.com/@agiammarchi/micro-repl/latest
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts):
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional): #336
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional):

Other information

I am working on a project that needs to show kids to grown up users: works in Chrome/ium and as long standing Web supporter this is one of those cases it's not me being sloppy on cross-browser testing, it's rather other vendors making it impossible for the project I am working on to work on "the Web Platform".

I have read almost the entirety of this thread #336 and had no chance to chime in but, for what I've understood, the security concern is not different from a basic <input type="file"> any malicious Web page could present, any malicious Web page could influence the user about what to upload, so that any malicious Web page could also read both sensible data or configuration files from any user surfing that malicious Web page.

While asking users to download an .exe file or anything like that instead which, once granted Admin privileges would harm them even more, seems like "the solution" to that thread, I am dealing with thousand of kids willing to just use their browsers to interact with "this or that SBC" so that when kids, or even adults, are using projects that are basing their default OS to Firefox, are incapable of learning, having fun, or create amazing projects out of the Web, which used to be a technology to enable everyone, not a technology to patronize and overload their ideas, or possibilities, instead.

Accordingly, as much as I'd love to remove the "need for Chrome/ium" mandatory alert on whatever I am building, these are days nobody can even blame the Web developer behind anymore, as constraints are all over the major vendors responsibility.

This is true for all MicroPython boards as well as Espruino or others, the need for a particular Web extension to do something otherwise impossible out of extensions (which are just yet another extra user explict intent) makes literally no sense, when an extension just lands over an extra explicit user consent.

I am hoping that anyone reading this might have a second thought, but I am unfortunately sure this will get blocked and closed at speed light instead, keeping the idea that Firefox is not what people think it is anymore, just another gatekeeping in the Web industry / reality üò•
items.title: Still on SerialPort API

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: CSS Nesting
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://drafts.csswg.org/css-nesting-1/#nest-rule
  • Explainer URL (if available):
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @tabatkins
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @emilio
  • WebKit position: WebKit/standards-positions#337

Other information

Basically this proposal from Tab.

I am a bit reluctant to ship this since we have a major open issue about how it should appear in CSSOM (w3c/csswg-drafts#10234), but apparently the CSSWG wants to ship @nest as currently specified now, then consider any additional changes later (w3c/csswg-drafts#10234 (comment), w3c/csswg-drafts#10234 (comment)).

So I am specifically asking for a position on shipping the (possibly intermediate) state of @nest as it's currently specified, despite w3c/csswg-drafts#10234 not being resolved.
items.title: CSS Nesting: @nest

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: document.caretPositionFromPoint API in shadow DOM scenario
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): w3c/csswg-drafts#9932
  • Explainer URL (if available):
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @siliu1
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1889503
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional):

Other information

FF's existing behavior is to let the API pierce any shadow roots. The new proposal is to provide the API with a new parameter which contains the shadow roots that the API can pierce into.
items.title: document.caretPositionFromPoint API in shadow DOM scenario

items.content_html:
Standards positions from other implementers can help our decision too and it's generally recommendable to file one if it's not already there.

WebKit has Mozilla s-p: https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/blob/ecf4b82adea6db85941fbaeb2a95b19724a814c8/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/request-for-position.yml?plain=1#L54-L58
items.title: Consider adding WebKit standards-position URL to the issue template

  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): whatwg/html#10269
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/guybedford/import-maps-extensions?tab=readme-ov-file#proposal
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @guybedford @yoavweiss
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional):

Other information

Currently it's impossible to use ES module imports in environments that require subresource integrity for security or privacy reasons. This is a relatively small addition to the platform that would enable it.
items.title: Importmap integrity

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Digital Credentials
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://wicg.github.io/digital-identities/
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/WICG/digital-identities/blob/main/proposals/identity-credential-proposal.md (to be updated - but still mostly accurate)
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @marcoscaceres @samuelgoto
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @bvandersloot-mozilla @martinthomson

Other information

The online digital credential space is complex space with lots of pieces, lots of uncertainty still, and perhaps a set of non-standardized browser-specific design properties. I think the useful review of this API is within the larger context and how having a browser API may make things better and/or worse, and the conditions (if any) under which Mozilla would be supportive of seeing this API added to the web. One possible useful resource is this talk I gave to PING at TPAC.
items.title: Digital Credentials
